exercises.title: Set Operations
exercises.description:
Given the sets $A = \{1, 2, 3, 4\}$ and $B = \{3, 4, 5, 6\}$. Determine:
1. $A \cup B$
2. $A \cap B$
3. $A \setminus B$
4. $B \setminus A$
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Determine the union $A \cup B$
$A \cup B = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$

Step 2: Determine the intersection $A \cap B$
$A \cap B = \{3, 4\}$

Step 3: Determine the difference $A \setminus B$
$A \setminus B = \{1, 2\}$

Step 4: Determine the difference $B \setminus A$
$B \setminus A = \{5, 6\}$

exercises.title: Subsets
exercises.description:
Which of the following statements are true?
1. $\{1, 2\} \subseteq \{1, 2, 3\}$
2. $\{1, 2, 3\} \subseteq \{1, 2\}$
3. $\emptyset \subseteq \{1, 2, 3\}$
4. $\{1, 2, 3\} \subseteq \emptyset$
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Check the definition of a subset
A set $A$ is a subset of $B$ if every element of $A$ is also contained in $B$.

Step 2: Analyze each statement individually
1. $\{1, 2\} \subseteq \{1, 2, 3\}$ is true, since every element of $\{1, 2\}$ is also in $\{1, 2, 3\}$.
2. $\{1, 2, 3\} \subseteq \{1, 2\}$ is false, since $3$ is not contained in $\{1, 2\}$.
3. $\emptyset \subseteq \{1, 2, 3\}$ is true, since the empty set is a subset of every set.
4. $\{1, 2, 3\} \subseteq \emptyset$ is false, since the empty set contains no elements.

Step 3: Determine the true statements
The true statements are 1 and 3.

exercises.title: Cartesian Product
exercises.description: Given the sets $A = \{a, b\}$ and $B = \{1, 2\}$. Determine $A \times B$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of the Cartesian product
The Cartesian product $A \times B$ is the set of all ordered pairs $(a,b)$ with $a \in A$ and $b \in B$.

Step 2: Determine all possible pairs
Possible pairs:
$(a,1)$, $(a,2)$
$(b,1)$, $(b,2)$

Step 3: Set up the Cartesian product
$A \times B = \{(a,1), (a,2), (b,1), (b,2)\}$

exercises.title: Mapping Properties
exercises.description: Examine the mapping $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $f(x) = x^2$ for injectivity and surjectivity. Justify your answer.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of injectivity
A mapping $f: A \rightarrow B$ is called injective if different elements from $A$ are mapped to different elements in $B$.

Step 2: Check for injectivity
For $f(x) = x^2$:
$f(-1) = f(1) = 1$
Thus, $f$ is not injective, as different elements are mapped to the same value.

Step 3: Definition of surjectivity
A mapping $f: A \rightarrow B$ is called surjective if every element from $B$ appears as an image.

Step 4: Check for surjectivity
For $f(x) = x^2$:
Negative numbers do not appear as images
Thus, $f$ is not surjective on $\mathbb{R}$

Step 5: Summary
The mapping $f(x) = x^2$ is neither injective nor surjective on $\mathbb{R}$.

exercises.title: Composition of Mappings
exercises.description: Given the mappings $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $f(x) = 2x + 1$ and $g: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $g(x) = x^2$. Determine $f\circ g$ and $g\circ f$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of composition
The composition $f\circ g$ is defined by $(f\circ g)(x) = f(g(x))$.

Step 2: Calculate $f\circ g$
$(f\circ g)(x) = f(g(x)) = f(x^2) = 2x^2 + 1$

Step 3: Calculate $g\circ f$
$(g\circ f)(x) = g(f(x)) = g(2x + 1) = (2x + 1)^2 = 4x^2 + 4x + 1$

Step 4: Compare the results
Comparison:
$f\circ g \neq g\circ f$
The composition of mappings is generally not commutative.

exercises.title: Set Identities
exercises.description:
Prove the distributive laws for sets:
1. $A \cap (B \cup C) = (A \cap B) \cup (A \cap C)$
2. $A \cup (B \cap C) = (A \cup B) \cap (A \cup C)$
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Formulate the distributive laws
To be proven are the distributive laws:
1. $A \cap (B \cup C) = (A \cap B) \cup (A \cap C)$
2. $A \cup (B \cap C) = (A \cup B) \cap (A \cup C)$

Step 2: Proof of the first distributive law
Let $x \in A \cap (B \cup C)$. Then:
$x \in A$ and $x \in B \cup C$
If $x \in B$, then $x \in A \cap B$
If $x \in C$, then $x \in A \cap C$
Thus $x \in (A \cap B) \cup (A \cap C)$

Step 3: Proof of the second distributive law
Let $x \in A \cup (B \cap C)$. Then:
$x \in A$ or $x \in B \cap C$
If $x \in A$, then $x \in A \cup B$ and $x \in A \cup C$
If $x \in B \cap C$, then $x \in B$ and $x \in C$
Thus $x \in (A \cup B) \cap (A \cup C)$

Step 4: Summary
The distributive laws show how intersection and union interact with each other.

exercises.title: Bijective Mappings
exercises.description: Show that the mapping $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $f(x) = x^3 + 2x$ is bijective. Determine the inverse mapping $f^{-1}$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Check for injectivity
Check the injectivity of $f(x) = x^3 + 2x$:
$f'(x) = 3x^2 + 2 > 0$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$
Thus, $f$ is strictly monotonically increasing and therefore injective.

Step 2: Check for surjectivity
Check the surjectivity:
$\lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} f(x) = -\infty$
$\lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} f(x) = \infty$
By the Intermediate Value Theorem, $f$ is surjective.

Step 3: Determine the inverse mapping
Determine the inverse mapping:
$y = x^3 + 2x$
Solving for $x$ gives the inverse mapping

Step 4: Verification
Verification:
$f(f^{-1}(y)) = y$
$f^{-1}(f(x)) = x$

exercises.title: Cardinality of Sets
exercises.description: Prove that the set of rational numbers $\mathbb{Q}$ is countably infinite.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of countability
A set is called countably infinite if it can be bijectively mapped to $\mathbb{N}$.

Step 2: Construct a bijection
Construct a bijection $\mathbb{Q} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}$:
Arrange the rational numbers in an infinite grid
Diagonal enumeration according to Cantor

Step 3: Prove the bijection
Proof of the bijection:
Every rational number is hit exactly once
Each natural number is assigned exactly one rational number

Step 4: Summary
The set of rational numbers is countably infinite, as it can be bijectively mapped to $\mathbb{N}$.

exercises.title: Equivalence Relations
exercises.description: Let $M$ be a non-empty set. Show that the relation $R = \{(A,B) \in P(M) \times P(M) \mid |A| = |B|\}$ is an equivalence relation on the power set $P(M)$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of equivalence relation
A relation $R$ on a set $M$ is called an equivalence relation if it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.

Step 2: Check for reflexivity
For every set $A \in P(M)$, $|A| = |A|$
Thus $(A,A) \in R$

Step 3: Check for symmetry
If $(A,B) \in R$, then $|A| = |B|$
Thus $|B| = |A|$ and $(B,A) \in R$

Step 4: Check for transitivity
If $(A,B) \in R$ and $(B,C) \in R$, then $|A| = |B|$ and $|B| = |C|$
Thus $|A| = |C|$ and $(A,C) \in R$

Step 5: Summary
The relation $R$ is an equivalence relation, as it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.

exercises.title: Power Set
exercises.description: Determine the power set $P(A)$ for $A = \{1, 2, 3\}$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of the power set
The power set $P(A)$ is the set of all subsets of $A$.

exercises.title: Set Equality
exercises.description: Are the sets $A = \{1, 2, 3\}$ and $B = \{3, 2, 1\}$ equal? Justify your answer.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of set equality
Two sets are equal if they contain the same elements, regardless of order.

Step 2: Check the elements
$A$ and $B$ contain the same elements: $1$, $2$, and $3$.

Step 3: Justify the answer
The sets are equal because they contain the same elements. The order does not matter for sets.

exercises.title: Inverse Mappings
exercises.description: Given the mapping $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $f(x) = 3x - 2$. Determine the inverse mapping $f^{-1}$ and show that $f^{-1}\circ f = id$ and $f\circ f^{-1} = id$ hold.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Determine the inverse mapping
Inverse mapping of $f(x) = 3x - 2$:
$y = 3x - 2$
$x = \frac{y + 2}{3}$
Thus $f^{-1}(y) = \frac{y + 2}{3}$

Step 2: Verify $f^{-1}\circ f = id$
Verification of $f^{-1}\circ f = id$:
$f^{-1}(f(x)) = f^{-1}(3x - 2) = \frac{(3x - 2) + 2}{3} = x$

Step 3: Verify $f\circ f^{-1} = id$
Verification of $f\circ f^{-1} = id$:
$f(f^{-1}(y)) = f(\frac{y + 2}{3}) = 3(\frac{y + 2}{3}) - 2 = y$

Step 4: Summary
The inverse mapping is correct, as both compositions yield the identity.

exercises.title: Set Operations with Intervals
exercises.description: Given the intervals $A = [0, 2]$ and $B = [1, 3]$. Determine $A \cap B$, $A \cup B$, and $A \setminus B$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Determine the intersection
$A \cap B = [1, 2]$

Step 2: Determine the union
$A \cup B = [0, 3]$

Step 3: Determine the difference
$A \setminus B = [0, 1)$

Step 4: Summary
The intervals show how set operations apply to continuous sets.

exercises.title: Cardinality of Sets
exercises.description: Show that the set of real numbers $\mathbb{R}$ is uncountable using Cantor's diagonal argument.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Introduction to Cantor's diagonal argument
Introduction to Cantor's diagonal argument:
Assume $\mathbb{R}$ is countable
Then there would be an enumeration of all real numbers

Step 2: Construct a real number
Construct a real number:
Take the $n$-th decimal place of the $n$-th number
Change this place
The resulting number cannot be in the enumeration

Step 3: Proof by contradiction
Proof by contradiction:
The constructed number contradicts the assumption of countability

Step 4: Summary
The set of real numbers is uncountable, as it cannot be bijectively mapped to $\mathbb{N}$.

exercises.title: Complex Set Operations
exercises.description:
Prove De Morgan's laws for sets:
1. $(A \cup B)^c = A^c \cap B^c$
2. $(A \cap B)^c = A^c \cup B^c$
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Formulate De Morgan's laws
De Morgan's laws for sets:
1. $(A \cup B)^c = A^c \cap B^c$
2. $(A \cap B)^c = A^c \cup B^c$

Step 2: Proof of the first law
$x \in (A \cup B)^c \Leftrightarrow x \notin A \cup B$
$\Leftrightarrow x \notin A$ and $x \notin B$
$\Leftrightarrow x \in A^c$ and $x \in B^c$
$\Leftrightarrow x \in A^c \cap B^c$

Step 3: Proof of the second law
$x \in (A \cap B)^c \Leftrightarrow x \notin A \cap B$
$\Leftrightarrow x \notin A$ or $x \notin B$
$\Leftrightarrow x \in A^c$ or $x \in B^c$
$\Leftrightarrow x \in A^c \cup B^c$

Step 4: Summary
De Morgan's laws show the relationship between complement, union, and intersection.

exercises.title: Set Operations with Number Sets
exercises.description:
Given the sets $A = \{x \in \mathbb{N} \mid x \leq 5\}$ and $B = \{x \in \mathbb{N} \mid x \text{ is even and } x \leq 8\}$. Determine:
1. $A \cup B$
2. $A \cap B$
3. $A \setminus B$
4. $B \setminus A$
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Determine the sets
$A = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5\}$
$B = \{2, 4, 6, 8\}$

Step 2: Determine the union
$A \cup B = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8\}$

Step 3: Determine the intersection
$A \cap B = \{2, 4\}$

Step 4: Determine the differences
$A \setminus B = \{1, 3, 5\}$
$B \setminus A = \{6, 8\}$

exercises.title: Subsets and Power Set
exercises.description: Given the set $A = \{a, b\}$. Determine all subsets of $A$ and show that the number of subsets is $2^{|A|}$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Determine the subsets
Subsets of $A = \{a, b\}$:
$\emptyset$
$\{a\}$
$\{b\}$
$\{a, b\}$

Step 2: Check the number
$|A| = 2$
Number of subsets = $2^2 = 4$

Step 3: Verification
The number of subsets matches the formula $2^{|A|}$.

exercises.title: Set Equality and Subsets
exercises.description:
Show that for arbitrary sets $A$ and $B$:
$A = B$ if and only if $A \subseteq B$ and $B \subseteq A$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Forward direction
If $A = B$, then obviously $A \subseteq B$ and $B \subseteq A$.

Step 2: Reverse direction
If $A \subseteq B$ and $B \subseteq A$, then:
Every element of $A$ is contained in $B$
Every element of $B$ is contained in $A$
Thus $A = B$

Step 3: Summary
The equivalence is proven.

exercises.title: Cartesian Product and Relations
exercises.description: Given the sets $A = \{1, 2\}$ and $B = \{a, b\}$. Determine $A \times B$ and give a relation $R \subseteq A \times B$ that represents a function.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Determine the Cartesian product
$A \times B = \{(1,a), (1,b), (2,a), (2,b)\}$

Step 2: Definition of a function
A function must assign exactly one element from $B$ to each element from $A$.

Step 3: Example of a function
$R = \{(1,a), (2,b)\}$ is a function, since:
- Each element from $A$ appears exactly once as the first component
- Each element from $A$ has exactly one image in $B$

exercises.title: Set Operations with Intervals
exercises.description: Given the intervals $A = (-\infty, 3]$ and $B = [1, \infty)$. Determine $A \cap B$ and $A \cup B$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Visualize the intervals
$A = (-\infty, 3]$
$B = [1, \infty)$

Step 2: Determine the intersection
$A \cap B = [1, 3]$

Step 3: Determine the union
$A \cup B = \mathbb{R}$

Step 4: Verification
The results can be verified by checking the endpoints.

exercises.title: Set Operations with Complements
exercises.description: Given the universal set $U = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5\}$ and the set $A = \{1, 3, 5\}$. Determine $A^c$ and show that $(A^c)^c = A$ holds.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Determine the complement
$A^c = U \setminus A = \{2, 4\}$

Step 2: Determine the complement of the complement
$(A^c)^c = U \setminus A^c = \{1, 3, 5\} = A$

Step 3: Verification
The equality $(A^c)^c = A$ is verified.

exercises.title: Set Operations with Number Sets
exercises.description: Given the sets $A = \{x \in \mathbb{Z} \mid -2 \leq x \leq 2\}$ and $B = \{x \in \mathbb{Z} \mid x \text{ is odd}\}$. Determine $A \cap B$ and $A \setminus B$.
solutionSteps:
Step 2: Determine the intersection
$A \cap B = \{-1, 1\}$

Step 3: Determine the difference
$A \setminus B = \{-2, 0, 2\}$

Step 4: Verification
The results can be verified by checking the elements.

exercises.title: Set Operations with Subsets
exercises.description:
Show that for arbitrary sets $A$, $B$, and $C$:
If $A \subseteq B$ and $B \subseteq C$, then $A \subseteq C$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Premises
$A \subseteq B$: Every element of $A$ is contained in $B$
$B \subseteq C$: Every element of $B$ is contained in $C$

Step 2: Proof
Let $x \in A$ be arbitrary
Then $x \in B$ (since $A \subseteq B$)
Then $x \in C$ (since $B \subseteq C$)
Thus $A \subseteq C$

Step 3: Summary
The transitivity of the subset relation is proven.

exercises.title: Mapping Properties
exercises.description: Examine the mapping $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $f(x) = |x|$ for injectivity and surjectivity. Justify your answer.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of the properties
A mapping is injective if different elements are mapped to different images.
A mapping is surjective if every element of the target set appears as an image.

Step 2: Check for injectivity
$f(-1) = f(1) = 1$
Thus, $f$ is not injective.

Step 3: Check for surjectivity
For every $y \geq 0$, there exists an $x$ with $f(x) = y$
For $y < 0$, there is no $x$ with $f(x) = y$
Thus, $f$ is not surjective on $\mathbb{R}$

Step 4: Summary
The mapping $f(x) = |x|$ is neither injective nor surjective on $\mathbb{R}$.

exercises.title: Composition of Mappings
exercises.description: Given the mappings $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $f(x) = x^2$ and $g: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $g(x) = \sqrt{x}$. Determine the maximal domain of definition of $g\circ f$ and $f\circ g$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Determine $g\circ f$
$(g\circ f)(x) = g(f(x)) = g(x^2) = \sqrt{x^2} = |x|$
Domain: $\mathbb{R}$

Step 2: Determine $f\circ g$
$(f\circ g)(x) = f(g(x)) = f(\sqrt{x}) = (\sqrt{x})^2 = x$
Domain: $[0, \infty)$

Step 3: Verification
The domains can be verified by checking the intermediate steps.

Step 4: Summary
The composition of mappings can restrict the domain.

exercises.title: Set Identities
exercises.description:
Prove the associative laws for sets:
1. $(A \cup B) \cup C = A \cup (B \cup C)$
2. $(A \cap B) \cap C = A \cap (B \cap C)$
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Formulate the associative laws
To be proven are the associative laws:
1. $(A \cup B) \cup C = A \cup (B \cup C)$
2. $(A \cap B) \cap C = A \cap (B \cap C)$

Step 2: Proof of the first law
$x \in (A \cup B) \cup C \Leftrightarrow x \in A \cup B$ or $x \in C$
$\Leftrightarrow x \in A$ or $x \in B$ or $x \in C$
$\Leftrightarrow x \in A$ or $x \in B \cup C$
$\Leftrightarrow x \in A \cup (B \cup C)$

Step 3: Proof of the second law
$x \in (A \cap B) \cap C \Leftrightarrow x \in A \cap B$ and $x \in C$
$\Leftrightarrow x \in A$ and $x \in B$ and $x \in C$
$\Leftrightarrow x \in A$ and $x \in B \cap C$
$\Leftrightarrow x \in A \cap (B \cap C)$

Step 4: Summary
The associative laws show that the order of operations does not matter for union and intersection.

exercises.title: Bijective Mappings
exercises.description: Show that the mapping $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $f(x) = 2x + 1$ is bijective. Determine the inverse mapping $f^{-1}$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Check for injectivity
$f(x_1) = f(x_2) \Rightarrow 2x_1 + 1 = 2x_2 + 1 \Rightarrow x_1 = x_2$
Thus, $f$ is injective.

Step 2: Check for surjectivity
For every $y \in \mathbb{R}$, there exists an $x = \frac{y-1}{2}$ with $f(x) = y$
Thus, $f$ is surjective.

Step 3: Determine the inverse mapping
$y = 2x + 1$
$x = \frac{y-1}{2}$
Thus $f^{-1}(y) = \frac{y-1}{2}$

exercises.title: Cardinality of Sets
exercises.description: Show that the set of natural numbers $\mathbb{N}$ and the set of even natural numbers $2\mathbb{N}$ are equinumerous.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of equinumerosity
Two sets are equinumerous if there is a bijection between them.

Step 2: Construct a bijection
$f: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow 2\mathbb{N}$, $f(n) = 2n$

Step 3: Prove the bijection
Injectivity: $f(n_1) = f(n_2) \Rightarrow 2n_1 = 2n_2 \Rightarrow n_1 = n_2$
Surjectivity: For every $m \in 2\mathbb{N}$, there exists an $n = \frac{m}{2} \in \mathbb{N}$ with $f(n) = m$

Step 4: Summary
The sets $\mathbb{N}$ and $2\mathbb{N}$ are equinumerous, as there is a bijection between them.

exercises.title: Equivalence Relations
exercises.description: Let $M$ be the set of all humans. Show that the relation $R = \{(a,b) \in M \times M \mid a \text{ and } b \text{ have the same birth year}\}$ is an equivalence relation.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of equivalence relation
A relation $R$ on a set $M$ is called an equivalence relation if it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.

Step 2: Check for reflexivity
For every person $a \in M$: $a$ has the same birth year as $a$
Thus $(a,a) \in R$

Step 3: Check for symmetry
If $(a,b) \in R$, then $a$ and $b$ have the same birth year
Thus $b$ and $a$ have the same birth year
Thus $(b,a) \in R$

Step 4: Check for transitivity
If $(a,b) \in R$ and $(b,c) \in R$, then $a$ and $b$ have the same birth year and $b$ and $c$ have the same birth year
Thus $a$ and $c$ have the same birth year
Thus $(a,c) \in R$

Step 5: Summary
The relation $R$ is an equivalence relation, as it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.

exercises.title: Power Set and Cardinality
exercises.description: Show that for a finite set $A$ with $|A| = n$, the cardinality of the power set $|P(A)| = 2^n$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of the power set
The power set $P(A)$ is the set of all subsets of $A$.

Step 2: Proof by complete induction
Base case: $n = 0$
$A = \emptyset$
$P(A) = \{\emptyset\}$
$|P(A)| = 1 = 2^0$

Step 3: Inductive step
Let $|A| = n+1$ and $a \in A$
Then $P(A) = P(A \setminus \{a\}) \cup \{B \cup \{a\} \mid B \in P(A \setminus \{a\})\}$
Thus $|P(A)| = 2|P(A \setminus \{a\})| = 2 \cdot 2^n = 2^{n+1}$

Step 4: Summary
The cardinality of the power set of an $n$-element set is $2^n$.

exercises.title: Cardinality of Sets
exercises.description: Show that the set of real numbers $\mathbb{R}$ and the set of real numbers in the interval $(0,1)$ are equinumerous.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of equinumerosity
Two sets are equinumerous if there is a bijection between them.

Step 2: Construct a bijection
$f: (0,1) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $f(x) = \tan(\pi x - \frac{\pi}{2})$

Step 3: Prove the bijection
Injectivity: The tangent function is strictly monotonically increasing on $(-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2})$
Surjectivity: The tangent function takes all real values

Step 4: Verification
The mapping is well-defined and bijective.

Step 5: Summary
The sets $\mathbb{R}$ and $(0,1)$ are equinumerous, as there is a bijection between them.

exercises.title: Complex Set Operations
exercises.description:
Prove the distributive laws for sets:
1. $A \cap (B \cup C) = (A \cap B) \cup (A \cap C)$
2. $A \cup (B \cap C) = (A \cup B) \cap (A \cup C)$
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Formulate the distributive laws
To be proven are the distributive laws:
1. $A \cap (B \cup C) = (A \cap B) \cup (A \cap C)$
2. $A \cup (B \cap C) = (A \cup B) \cap (A \cup C)$

Step 2: Proof of the first law
$x \in A \cap (B \cup C) \Leftrightarrow x \in A$ and $x \in B \cup C$
$\Leftrightarrow x \in A$ and ($x \in B$ or $x \in C$)
$\Leftrightarrow (x \in A$ and $x \in B)$ or $(x \in A$ and $x \in C)$
$\Leftrightarrow x \in (A \cap B) \cup (A \cap C)$

Step 3: Proof of the second law
$x \in A \cup (B \cap C) \Leftrightarrow x \in A$ or $x \in B \cap C$
$\Leftrightarrow x \in A$ or ($x \in B$ and $x \in C$)
$\Leftrightarrow (x \in A$ or $x \in B)$ and $(x \in A$ or $x \in C)$
$\Leftrightarrow x \in (A \cup B) \cap (A \cup C)$

Step 4: Summary
The distributive laws show the relationship between intersection and union.

exercises.title: Cardinality of Sets
exercises.description: Show that the set of rational numbers $\mathbb{Q}$ and the set of natural numbers $\mathbb{N}$ are equinumerous.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of equinumerosity
Two sets are equinumerous if there is a bijection between them.

Step 2: Construct a bijection
Arrange the rational numbers in an infinite grid
Diagonal enumeration according to Cantor

Step 3: Prove the bijection
Every rational number is hit exactly once
Each natural number is assigned exactly one rational number

Step 4: Verification
The mapping is well-defined and bijective.

Step 5: Summary
The sets $\mathbb{Q}$ and $\mathbb{N}$ are equinumerous, as there is a bijection between them.

exercises.title: Equivalence Relations
exercises.description: Let $M$ be the set of all lines in the plane. Show that the relation $R = \{(g,h) \in M \times M \mid g \text{ and } h \text{ are parallel}\}$ is an equivalence relation.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of equivalence relation
A relation $R$ on a set $M$ is called an equivalence relation if it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.

Step 2: Check for reflexivity
Every line is parallel to itself
Thus $(g,g) \in R$

Step 3: Check for symmetry
If $g$ is parallel to $h$, then $h$ is parallel to $g$
Thus $(g,h) \in R \Rightarrow (h,g) \in R$

Step 4: Check for transitivity
If $g$ is parallel to $h$ and $h$ is parallel to $k$, then $g$ is parallel to $k$
Thus $(g,h) \in R$ and $(h,k) \in R \Rightarrow (g,k) \in R$

Step 5: Summary
The relation $R$ is an equivalence relation, as it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.

exercises.title: Power Set and Cardinality
exercises.description: Show that the power set of an infinite set is uncountable.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of the power set
The power set $P(A)$ is the set of all subsets of $A$.

Step 2: Proof by contradiction
Assume $P(A)$ is countable
Then there would be an enumeration of all subsets of $A$

Step 3: Construct a subset
Construct a subset $B \subseteq A$:
For each $a \in A$:
- If $a \in A_n$, then $a \notin B$
- If $a \notin A_n$, then $a \in B$
The resulting set $B$ cannot be in the enumeration

Step 4: Contradiction
The constructed set $B$ contradicts the assumption of countability

Step 5: Summary
The power set of an infinite set is uncountable.

exercises.title: Complex Set Operations
exercises.description:
Prove De Morgan's laws for sets:
1. $(A \cup B)^c = A^c \cap B^c$
2. $(A \cap B)^c = A^c \cup B^c$
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Formulate De Morgan's laws
De Morgan's laws for sets:
1. $(A \cup B)^c = A^c \cap B^c$
2. $(A \cap B)^c = A^c \cup B^c$

Step 2: Proof of the first law
$x \in (A \cup B)^c \Leftrightarrow x \notin A \cup B$
$\Leftrightarrow x \notin A$ and $x \notin B$
$\Leftrightarrow x \in A^c$ and $x \in B^c$
$\Leftrightarrow x \in A^c \cap B^c$

Step 3: Proof of the second law
$x \in (A \cap B)^c \Leftrightarrow x \notin A \cap B$
$\Leftrightarrow x \notin A$ or $x \notin B$
$\Leftrightarrow x \in A^c$ or $x \in B^c$
$\Leftrightarrow x \in A^c \cup B^c$

Step 4: Summary
De Morgan's laws show the relationship between complement, union, and intersection.

exercises.title: Cardinality of Sets
exercises.description: Show that the set of real numbers $\mathbb{R}$ and the set of real numbers in the interval $[0,1]$ are equinumerous.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of equinumerosity
Two sets are equinumerous if there is a bijection between them.

Step 2: Construct a bijection
$f: [0,1] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $f(x) = \tan(\pi x - \frac{\pi}{2})$

Step 3: Prove the bijection
Injectivity: The tangent function is strictly monotonically increasing on $(-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2})$
Surjectivity: The tangent function takes all real values

Step 4: Verification
The mapping is well-defined and bijective.

Step 5: Summary
The sets $\mathbb{R}$ and $[0,1]$ are equinumerous, as there is a bijection between them.

exercises.title: Equivalence Relations
exercises.description: Let $M$ be the set of all polynomials with real coefficients. Show that the relation $R = \{(p,q) \in M \times M \mid p \text{ and } q \text{ have the same degree}\}$ is an equivalence relation.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of equivalence relation
A relation $R$ on a set $M$ is called an equivalence relation if it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.

Step 2: Check for reflexivity
Every polynomial has the same degree as itself
Thus $(p,p) \in R$

Step 3: Check for symmetry
If $p$ and $q$ have the same degree, then $q$ and $p$ have the same degree
Thus $(p,q) \in R \Rightarrow (q,p) \in R$

Step 4: Check for transitivity
If $p$ and $q$ have the same degree and $q$ and $r$ have the same degree, then $p$ and $r$ have the same degree
Thus $(p,q) \in R$ and $(q,r) \in R \Rightarrow (p,r) \in R$

Step 5: Summary
The relation $R$ is an equivalence relation, as it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.

exercises.title: Power Set and Cardinality
exercises.description: Show that the power set of a countably infinite set is uncountable.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of the power set
The power set $P(A)$ is the set of all subsets of $A$.

Step 2: Proof by contradiction
Assume $P(A)$ is countable
Then there would be an enumeration of all subsets of $A$

Step 3: Construct a subset
Construct a subset $B \subseteq A$:
For each $a \in A$:
- If $a \in A_n$, then $a \notin B$
- If $a \notin A_n$, then $a \in B$
The resulting set $B$ cannot be in the enumeration

Step 4: Contradiction
The constructed set $B$ contradicts the assumption of countability

Step 5: Summary
The power set of a countably infinite set is uncountable.
